items.title: Cannot run codecov with --tries flag
items.body:
I tried uploading with the below command
```sh
codecov --token=***** --required -X s3 --tries=5
```

The [tries flag] is one of the advanced arguments.

However I got error with this flag.
```sh
codecov: error: unrecognized arguments: --tries=5
```

Is this a bug? Or how can I use this flag?

[tries flag]: https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/blob/master/codecov/__init__.py#L410

items.title: Codecov v2.1.6 Fail when using coverage
items.body:
v2.1.6 has lock the coverage dependency to v4.5.4

Now the integration is broken (at least in Python 3.8)

```
==> Collecting reports
 
    Generating coverage xml reports for Python
 
    Error running `['/usr/local/bin/python', '-m', 'coverage', 'xml', '-i']`: Command '['/usr/local/bin/python', '-m', 'coverage', 'xml', '-i']' returned non-zero exit status 1.
 
    - Ignored: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/root/app/src/coverage.xml'
 
Error: No coverage report found

Tip: See all example repositories: https://github.com/codecov?query=example
 
```

With coverage 5.1 it was working fine

items.title: Version 2.1.3 fails to find gcov files
items.body:
Recently codecov stopped uploading my C code coverage on a Python C extension I have written.

In [this job](https://github.com/pganssle/zoneinfo/runs/696921785?check_suite_focus=true), `tox` is using `codecov==2.1.1`, and the upload succeeds.

In [this job](https://github.com/pganssle/zoneinfo/runs/697452420?check_suite_focus=true), `tox` is using `codecov==2.1.3` and I see the following error:

```
==> Detecting CI provider
  -> Got branch from git/hg
  -> Got sha from git/hg
==> Preparing upload
==> Processing gcov (disable by -X gcov)
    Executing gcov (gcov -pb  .../zoneinfo/.tox/gcov/coverage/build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/lib/zoneinfo_module.gcno)
    Error running `gcov -pb  .../zoneinfo/.tox/gcov/coverage/build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/lib/zoneinfo_module.gcno`: 
        [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'gcov -pb  .../zoneinfo/.tox/gcov/coverage/build/temp.linux-x86_64-3.8/lib/zoneinfo_module.gcno'
Error: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'replace'
```

(I've modified this slightly to make it a bit easier to read by shortening some paths and breaking up one extra long line).

Unfortunately I don't have time to create a minimal reproducer, but if you clone [the zoneinfo repository](https://github.com/pganssle/zoneinfo) and run `tox -e gcov`, that should generate the coverage files, and I'm using `scripts/upload_codecov.py` to upload the coverage files — it is just a script that finds the XML file output that `gcovr` emits, and passes that to `codecov -f`.

I'm guessing https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/issues/167 is the culprit.

items.title: Tags and changelog for 2.1.x?
items.body: It looks like 2.1.0 and 2.1.1 have hit PyPI, but I don't see tags in git. (2.0.22 is also missing from the changelog.) Would you mind pushing these up?

items.title: HTTP 400 while uploading to s3 with python codecov
items.body:
We have a public repo which is built on Drone.io and everything was fine until yesterday...
According to the [Codecov commit history](https://codecov.io/gh/PyTorchLightning/pytorch-lightning/branch/master/commits?page=1) the reports start failing about 24h ago without any change in Codecov config or CI configuration...
It seems to be strictly failing on uploading to S3, see the error:
```
+ codecov --token $CODECOV_TOKEN
--
1765 | find: unknown predicate `-not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**''
1766 |  
1767 | _____          _
1768 | / ____\|        \| \|
1769 | \| \|     ___   __\| \| ___  ___ _____   __
1770 | \| \|    / _ \ / _  \|/ _ \/ __/ _ \ \ / /
1771 | \| \|___\| (_) \| (_\| \|  __/ (_\| (_) \ V /
1772 | \_____\___/ \____\|\___\|\___\___/ \_/
1773 | v2.0.22
1774 |  
1775 | ==> Detecting CI provider
1776 | -> Got branch from git/hg
1777 | -> Got sha from git/hg
1778 | ==> Preparing upload
1779 | ==> Processing gcov (disable by -X gcov)
1780 | Executing gcov (['find', '/drone/src', "-not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**'", '-type', 'f', '-name', '*.gcno', '', '-exec', 'gcov', '-pb', '', '{}', '+'])
1781 | Error running `['find', '/drone/src', "-not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**'", '-type', 'f', '-name', '*.gcno', '', '-exec', 'gcov', '-pb', '', '{}', '+']`: Command '['find', '/drone/src', "-not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**'", '-type', 'f', '-name', '*.gcno', '', '-exec', 'gcov', '-pb', '', '{}', '+']' returned non-zero exit status 1.
1782 | ==> Collecting reports
1783 | Generating coverage xml reports for Python
1784 | + /drone/src/coverage.xml bytes=175982
1785 | ==> Uploading
1786 | .url https://codecov.io
1787 | .query commit=07b61c36d7ed5d6a731cd06096f967b85d1a2b92&branch=master&token=<secret>&yaml=.codecov.yml&package=py2.0.22
1788 | Pinging Codecov...
1789 | Uploading to S3...
1790 | Error: 400 Client Error: Bad Request for url: https://storage.googleapis.com/codecov/v4/raw/2020-05-17/58A692D2985A264F96A68126BE73B9B0/07b61c36d7ed5d6a731cd06096f967b85d1a2b92/8e03c21c-d0d8-4fc3-91c7-805790ffbff4.txt?X-Amz-Algorithm=AWS4-HMAC-SHA256&X-Amz-Credential=GOOG1EQX6OZVJGHKK3633AAFGLBUCOOATRACRQRQF6HMSMLYUP6EAD6XSWAAY%2F20200517%2FUS%2Fs3%2Faws4_request&X-Amz-Date=20200517T212109Z&X-Amz-Expires=10&X-Amz-SignedHeaders=host&X-Amz-Signature=8d778eb999bad1df2ef43dd5d9eef1ae407b032f69162876568618cf8469bbad
1791 |  
1792 | Tip: See all example repositories: https://github.com/codecov?query=example
1793 | Support channels:
1794 | Email:   hello@codecov.io
1795 | IRC:     #codecov
1796 | Gitter:  https://gitter.im/codecov/support
1797 | Twitter: @codecov
```
see: http://35.192.60.23/PyTorchLightning/pytorch-lightning/2962/1/2
the very same issue was also reported on support by others:
https://community.codecov.io/t/http-400-while-uploading-to-s3-with-python-codecov-from-travis/1428

items.title: find: unknown predicate `-not -path '
items.body:
We see this error on CircleCI builds: eg: https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/zulip/zulip/7488/workflows/7906c5d1-5032-47a1-88f3-60e79a9631d1/jobs/43293/parallel-runs/0/steps/0-114

```
find: unknown predicate `-not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**''
 
    Error running `['find', '/home/circleci/zulip', "-not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**'", '-type', 'f', '-name', '*.gcno', '', '-exec', 'gcov', '-pb', '', '{}', '+']`: Command '['find', '/home/circleci/zulip', "-not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**'", '-type', 'f', '-name', '*.gcno', '', '-exec', 'gcov', '-pb', '', '{}', '+']' returned non-zero exit status 1.
```

When running:
```
pip install codecov && codecov
```

Pinning the version of `codecov==2.0.15` fixes this (since it doesn't use `find`.)

We use `buildpack-deps:bionic-scm` as our base image for CI builds.

Our CI config file - https://github.com/zulip/zulip/blob/master/.circleci/config.yml

Let me know if you need any more details to debug this.

items.title: Failure in the `gcov` processing `find` command, whose test is AWOL
items.body:
The `gcov` processing command issued by `codecov` contains malformed `find` predicates, and always fails. The failure looks like this:

![Screen Shot 2020-04-08 at 1 45 10 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/378969/78748792-dceff980-793a-11ea-84c6-c059c0c836c4.jpg)

… this is on macOS, which offers BSD `find` as the default. I verified the failure by [installing GNU `findutils` with Homebrew](https://formulae.brew.sh/formula/findutils#default) and changing a local clone of `codecov` to use that (as `/usr/local/bin/gfind`) – the error message is slightly more helpful:

```bash
`/usr/local/bin/gfind /Users/fish/Dropbox/CLU/clu -not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**' -type f -name *.gcno  -exec gcov -pb  {} +` exited with status 1, error: “gfind: paths must precede expression: `'”
```

… the relevant `gcov`-related test is, I think, the only test in the `codecov` suite that is [completely commented out and skipped](https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/blob/800d1ad035e65987b094781bb328fb06e1c0e8a1/tests/test.py#L250-L259):

```python
    def test_gcov(self):
        self.skipTest("Need to fix this test...")
        # if self._env.get('TRAVIS') == 'true':
        #     self.write_c()
        #     output = self.run_cli(token='a', branch='b', commit='c')
        #     self.assertEqual(os.path.exists('hello.c.gcov'), True)
        #     report = output['reports'].split('<<<<<< network\n')[1].splitlines()
        #     self.assertIn('hello.c.gcov', report[0])
        # else:
        #     self.skipTest("Skipped, works on Travis only.")
```

… which suggests at least an acknowledgement of the problem, if not a genesis of same.

items.title: Codecov v2.0.20 fails in Alpine Linux
items.body:
After upgrading from 2.0.15 to 2.0.20 the codecov command fails with the following error:

```
Executing gcov (['find', '/project', "-not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**'", '-type', 'f', '-name', '*.gcno', '', '-exec', 'gcov', '-pb', '', '{}', '+'])
find: unrecognized: -not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**'
```

After that it prints the usage of find:

```
BusyBox v1.31.1 () multi-call binary.
Usage: find [-HL] [PATH]... [OPTIONS] [ACTIONS]
```

Where `BusyBox` is probably a clue to the problem. Codecov probably expects GNU find?

items.title: codecov's S3 upload doesn't report failure but reported URL has no data
items.body:
After generating a merged coverage report and using codecov to process and upload it, the tool reports that it uploads the result to S3. Additionally, it outputs a URL where the report can be found. In this instance, we're using AppVeyor.

When going to this URL, I'm greeted with the message "Unable to find report content in the storage archive." The page displays another large message asking if the repo is private (which it is not).

The command-line tool doesn't report any errors and the output from the codecov tools is identical to when it was working and provided a link to a page with valid results.

Here is the output of the command:

```
The filename, directory name, or volume label syntax is incorrect.
The filename, directory name, or volume label syntax is incorrect.
abort: no repository found in 'C:\projects\[our project]\build' (.hg not found)!
      _____          _
     / ____|        | |
    | |     ___   __| | ___  ___ _____   __
    | |    / _ \ / _  |/ _ \/ __/ _ \ \ / /
    | |___| (_) | (_| |  __/ (_| (_) \ V /
     \_____\___/ \____|\___|\___\___/ \_/
                                    v2.0.15
==> Detecting CI provider
    AppVeyor Detected
==> Preparing upload
    Error running `cd 'C:\projects\[our project]\build' && git ls-files`: None
    Error running `cd 'C:\projects\[our project]\build' && hg locate`: None
    Error running `hg locate`: None
XX> Skip processing gcov
==> Collecting reports
XX> Searching for reports disabled
    Targeting specific files
    + coverage_pathsfixed.xml bytes=1567145
==> Uploading
    .url https://codecov.io
    .query service=appveyor&package=py2.0.15&job=[our project]%2F[our project]%2F3.99.1084&build=xxxxxxxx&branch=development&commit=xxxxxxxx&slug=[our project]%2F[our project]
    Pinging Codecov...
    Uploading to S3...
    https://codecov.io/github/[our project]/[our project]/commit/xxxxxxxxxx
Build success
```

I'm not sure what could be going wrong but was there a major change in the code recently which would force us to update our config or some other setting?

items.title: codecov stopped adding GitHub PR comments
items.body:
My team repo (https://github.com/google/go-cloud) has the Codedov GitHub app installed, and a [codecov .yaml file](https://github.com/google/go-cloud/blob/master/.codecov.yml). Comments used to work fine ([example](https://github.com/google/go-cloud/pull/2299#issuecomment-501022979)), but about 2 weeks ago they stopped ([example PR](https://github.com/google/go-cloud/pull/2377) with passing tests but no comment).

The upload to codecov appears to work fine; there are no errors, and the URL in the output goes to a page that looks correct. Example:

```
  _____          _
 / ____|        | |
| |     ___   __| | ___  ___ _____   __
| |    / _ \ / _` |/ _ \/ __/ _ \ \ / /
| |___| (_) | (_| |  __/ (_| (_) \ V /
 \_____\___/ \__,_|\___|\___\___/ \_/
                              Bash-8a28df4
==> Travis CI detected.
    project root: .
    Fixing merge commit SHA
    Yaml found at: .codecov.yml
==> Running gcov in . (disable via -X gcov)
==> Python coveragepy not found
==> Searching for coverage reports in:
    + .
    -> Found 1 reports
==> Detecting git/mercurial file structure
==> Appending build variables
    + TRAVIS_OS_NAME
    + _TRAVIS_RESOLVED_GIMME_GO_VERSION_INT
==> Reading reports
    + ./coverage.out bytes=15268975
==> Appending adjustments
    http://docs.codecov.io/docs/fixing-reports
    + Found adjustments
==> Gzipping contents
==> Uploading reports
    url: https://codecov.io
    query: branch=master&commit=ae2ed6be523c1855b1f2a2e12a43ab392b4754de&build=6599.1&build_url=&name=&tag=&slug=google%2Fgo-cloud&service=travis&flags=&pr=2398&job=210598986
    -> Pinging Codecov
https://codecov.io/upload/v4?package=bash-8a28df4&token=&branch=master&commit=ae2ed6be523c1855b1f2a2e12a43ab392b4754de&build=6599.1&build_url=&name=&tag=&slug=google%2Fgo-cloud&service=travis&flags=&pr=2398&job=210598986
    -> Uploading
    -> View reports at https://codecov.io/github/google/go-cloud/commit/ae2ed6be523c1855b1f2a2e12a43ab392b4754de
```

(and the URL at the bottom of that snippet looks fine).

Any suggestions on what could be going wrong?

items.title: codecov in gitlab CI/CD didn't aware of new commits
items.body:
This is what my codecov dashboard looks like:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17734314/55292384-73c6d380-5414-11e9-84c0-c1cc9e1c1735.png)

It say that 'master' commit was 12 ago. But turn out:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17734314/55292396-8fca7500-5414-11e9-942f-94378011b287.png)

I have many commit in [master](https://gitlab.com/azzamsa/lupv) that codecov not aware of.

It build and generated [coverage.xml succesfully](https://gitlab.com/azzamsa/lupv/-/jobs/187552121), but I don't know why codecov is not aware of it.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17734314/55292411-da4bf180-5414-11e9-966a-01abfc061cb4.png)

So the badge still say it's 45% where the real coverage is 70% in my dashboard.

Is this because all my master had the same commit message with devel branch ? this is my workflow, I rarely push to master direcly, but using merge from devel branch.

Any suggestion ?

Thank you.

items.title: Recognizes function run, but doesn't track
items.body: For a given function, codecov will flag a definition line as hit, but then any line within the function doesn't get hit (https://codecov.io/gh/XPRESSyourself/XPRESStools/src/master/xpresstools/fetch.py). This seems likely as when I run the tests manually, I get the expected output which would require using the lines within the function. Here is the corresponding test file (https://github.com/XPRESSyourself/XPRESStools/blob/master/tests/fetch_test.py) which is checking that the function is returning a dataframe equal to the truth dataframe. Any idea what the issue is here?

items.title: codecov must exit code !=0 for failures
items.body:
**tl;dr** `codecov` is returning exit code `0` when it fails. The process should return a non-zero value (typically `1`) for failures. In my case, a schell script cannot deteremine if `codecov` fails. There appears to be some runs of codecov that clearly fail yet the process exit code is `0` (which means success for shell scripts). This is makes `codecov` unreliable. ## Some examples where `codecov` fails yet return code is `0`. I could probably find more. I suspect it's never setting it's the exit code. ### unset repository upload token ``` $ codecov --file coverage.xml The filename, directory name, or volume label syntax is incorrect. _____ _ / ____| | | | | ___ __| | ___ ___ _____ __ | | / _ \ / _ |/ _ \/ __/ _ \ \ / / | |___| (_) | (_| | __/ (_| (_) \ V / \_____\___/ \____|\___|\___\___/ \_/ v2.0.15 ==> Detecting CI provider -> Got branch from git/hg -> Got sha from git/hg ==> Preparing upload Error running `cd 'C:\Users\user1\Projects\project1' && git ls-files`: None Error: Missing repository upload token ... $ echo $? 0 ``` ### bad token ``` export CODECOV_TOKEN=foobar $ codecov --file coverage.xml ... Error: HTTP 400 Provided token is not a UUID. ... $ echo $? 0 ``` ### missing file ``` $ codecov --file does_not_exist.xml ... Error: No coverage report found ... $ echo $? 0 ```
You get the idea.

items.title: Codecov not posting coverage report on pull requests
items.body:
I am facing a problem with the feature “codecov will generate a mini code coverage report and post it as a comment to the pull request”, I am getting it for a public repository of mine easily, but, not for a private one. Is there any specific procedure for private repositories? 
Code coverage report for both, public and private, repositories gets uploaded successfully on CodeCov, no issues there.

items.title: Codecov doesn't update github PR status
items.body:
Hi all,

I'm pretty sure this is the wrong place to post this, but I don't know where else to turn.
I have a github repo [1], and run my tests using Travis CI. The results are uploaded to codecov without issues; let's take PR 96 [2] as an example. The Travis run is here: [3]. The coverage data does make it to CodeCov [4]. 
However, CodeCov does *not* post a PR status. I have a .codecov.yml [5], and I have CodeCov's GitHub webhook integration enabled for the repository. CodeCov.io detects this in the reposettings. 
I'm at a loss at what to try next; does anyone have an idea?

Peter

[1] https://github.com/marrink-lab/vermouth-martinize/
[2] https://github.com/marrink-lab/vermouth-martinize/pull/96

items.title: "Generating coverage xml reports for Python" is slow
items.body: "Generating coverage xml reports for Python" takes ~30 seconds for a relatively small project on circleci. Is there some way (args / cache) to speed up this stage?

items.title: codecov exclude_lines
items.body:
Hello!
I am trying to exclude code in the tox report, from what I gathered online I am trying to use the following in my **tox.ini** file:
```
[report]
exclude_lines=
    pragma: no cover
    pragma: ${MYSQL_TESTS} cover

```
But it doesn't seem to work, especially for the **environment variable** (spawning a docker container where I run all tests), for example **MYSQL_TESTS=NO**.

On my code i have it something like

- for env. variable pragma, expecting the whole function/class to be excluded:
```
def foo(params):  # NO cover
    ...
```
- for normal pragma, expecting the whole function/class to be excluded:
```
def foo(params):  # no cover
    ...
```
---
Some modules dont have to be tested, when another module is being tested, and I am trying to exclude them from the final report (when I test for mongo, dont include sql code in the coverage report).

This report right here:

![screenshot 2018-06-13 10 02 18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4501464/41337909-eb5286e2-6ef0-11e8-9813-d1ed895e4538.png)

The way I run my tests is:

```
[tox]
envlist = py36
setupdir = /app/src/

[testenv]
passenv = *

deps =
        --upgrade
        -r/app/src/requirements.txt
        -r/app/tests/requirements.txt

commands =
        nosetests -w /app/tests --with-xunit --xunit-file=/output/nosetests.xml \
            --with-coverage --cover-erase \
            --cover-package=adapters --cover-package=esm \
            --cover-min-percentage=70
        codecov -e TOXENV
```
Could someone help me out please? Am i setting this wrong?

items.title: namespace depth > 1 causes "Error: HTTP 400" on Gitlab
items.body:
**How to reproduce:**
1. Create an organisation with a subproject: gitlab.com/myorg/subgroup/myrepo
2. Run tests and upload using `codecov`

**Error message**
==> Detecting CI provider
    Gitlab CI Detected
==> Preparing upload
==> Processing gcov (disable by -X gcov)
    Executing gcov (find /builds/myorg/subgroup/myrepo -not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**' -type f -name '*.gcno'  -exec gcov -pb  {} +)
==> Collecting reports
    Generating coverage xml reports for Python
    + /builds/myorg/subgroup/myrepo/coverage.xml bytes=100016
==> Uploading
    .url https://codecov.io
    .query service=gitlab&package=py2.0.15&token=<secret>&build=63840040&branch=test%2Fcoverage&commit=57dd41a7d05fc84f1a039231575071eb8effa565&slug=myorg%2Fsubgroup%2Fmyrepo
    Pinging Codecov...
Error: HTTP 400
slug must match pattern ^[\w\-\.]{1,255}\/[\w\-\.]{1,255}$

**Workaround:**
add the following snippet in the CI script
```
CI_PROJECT_BASEDIR=$(basename ${CI_PROJECT_DIR})
cd ${CI_PROJECT_DIR}/.. && mv ${CI_PROJECT_BASEDIR} .. \
&& cd ../${CI_PROJECT_BASEDIR}
```
**Tentative solution:** 
change regex to 
`^[\w\-\.]{1,255}(?>\/[\w\-\.]{1,255}){1,}$`

items.title: Does codecov support multiple branches?
items.body:
If my repo does have a `.codecov.yml` file [like this](https://github.com/marlonbymendes/2018.1-Cardinals/commit/cd37bf83c737c324f7084910ed7d087d6c607118), configured for branch `codecov`, codecov.io/ shows code coverage only for the branch `codecov`, even if I commit on other branches.

However, if my repo doesn't have the file  `.codecov.yml`, codecov.io/ will only show code coverage for the default branch on GitHub, which is `develop`. That's why I ask: Does codecov support multiple branches? How can I do so?

items.title: Support AWS CodeBuild projects
items.body:
Hello, thanks for the great work at CodeCov. We use it in several projects, and have recently ported from CircleCI to AWS CodeBuild (for price and AWS CodePipeline integration).

We are currently using the codecov shell script and doing some shell magic to make it all work. It would be wonderful if CodeBuild was supported "automagically" like the other CI providers.

If it helps, here is what we've done so far, and it seems to mostly be working. Once we pull the plug on Circle completely, we'll know if the uploads to master are working correctly.

`VCS_PULL_REQUEST=$(echo $CODEBUILD_SOURCE_VERSION | grep pr | sed 's/pr\///g')`

With that set, the git fallback seems to be handling the rest.

Here are the CodeBuild environment variables:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codebuild/latest/userguide/build-env-ref-env-vars.html

Thanks!

items.title: CircleCI: No .coverage file found.
items.body:
I've been having issues generating coverage reports for a Flask application in a private repository in CircleCI. I am able to do so locally by running ``codecov -t TOKEN``, however, in the CI I get the following when running the same command:

```

      _____          _
     / ____|        | |
    | |     ___   __| | ___  ___ _____   __
    | |    / _ \ / _  |/ _ \/ __/ _ \ \ / /
    | |___| (_) | (_| |  __/ (_| (_) \ V /
     \_____\___/ \____|\___|\___\___/ \_/
                                    v2.0.15

==> Detecting CI provider
    Circle CI Detected
==> Preparing upload
==> Processing gcov (disable by -X gcov)
    Executing gcov (find /home/circleci/repo -not -path './bower_components/**' -not -path './node_modules/**' -not -path './vendor/**' -type f -name '*.gcno'  -exec gcov -pb  {} +)
==> Collecting reports
Error: No coverage report found
```

I received the same error when trying to command recommended by CircleCI's [docs](https://circleci.com/docs/1.0/code-coverage/):

```
bash <(curl -s https://codecov.io/bash)
```

Seems like CodeCov is failing to generate ``coverage.xml`` on CircleCI, any ideas what could cause this?

_codecov.yml_

```
codecov:
  branch: master
coverage:
  status:
    patch: false
    project:
      default:
        target: '70'
        threshold: '0.1'
        branches: null
        only_pulls: false
```

items.title: Regression in v2.0.13: running "coverage combine" overrides existing .coverage
items.body:
After I run `pytest` with coverage enabled (through `--cov` option),  I have some empty ill-formatted `.coverage.*` files (I will not go into details why, I am not 100% sure exactly, probably this has to do with `Pool.join` not being called in some places).

An example of .coverage* files I have after the `pytest --cov` run (taken from this Travis [log](https://travis-ci.org/lesteve/joblib/jobs/329948292#L2239)):
```
-rw-r--r-- 1 travis travis    0 Jan 17 16:49 .coverage.travis-job-lesteve-joblib-329948292.travisci.net.2842.950710
-rw-r--r-- 1 travis travis    0 Jan 17 16:50 .coverage.travis-job-lesteve-joblib-329948292.travisci.net.3588.085891
-rw-r--r-- 1 travis travis  22K Jan 17 16:52 .coverage
-rw-r--r-- 1 travis travis 2.6K Jan 17 16:52 .coverage.travis-job-lesteve-joblib-329948292.travisci.net.5223.980799
```

Since v2.0.13 (and this [commit](https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/commit/6354ac225a9413cc19d6418e4829d9376d22ad14#diff-ed4cb86e1f4a5c5feeecc37b90ec6a23)), `coverage combine` is run under the hood by `codecov`. In a setup like mine this will override the existing `.coverage` and result in partial coverage (actually in my case the coverage drop to near zero, because the .coverage.* are very small).

I tried to call `coverage combine -a` before calling `codecov` and that fixes the issue, so you probably want to do that (as well as in the bash tool) unless there is something I am missing.

items.title: Upload failure:  'ascii' codec can't decode
items.body:
```
==> Uploading
    .url https://codecov.io
    .query service=circleci&package=py2.0.11&yaml=codecov.yml&job=2049.0&build=2049.0&branch=lll&commit=22110560b5107497a72d0888b70fa7b8d8f128e8&slug=ethereum%2Fcpp-ethereum

    Uploading to S3...
Error: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe2 in position 12947300: ordinal not in range(128)
```

items.title: Revert #118
items.body:
The change made in #118 looks good on the surface, but completely changed the meaning of the code and broke it :-). See https://github.com/codecov/codecov-bash/issues/106

Anyone with write access to this repo should be able to do this trivially by clicking the "revert" button in #118's history.

CC: @blueyed @stevepeak

items.title: Amazon S3 Reduced Redundancy costs more than Standard
items.body: Amazon isn't keeping Reduced Redundancy to be cheaper than Stardand storage. It actually costs more for less data durability. Should codecov be changed to use Standard storage?

items.title: [BUG] Broken AppVeyor autodetection
items.body:
Current vars are:
```python
CI=True
APPVEYOR=true
```

But the code checks equality to `True` (as in official docs). I guess they broke this at some point.

Ref: https://github.com/appveyor/ci/issues/1853

items.title: Allow selection of the coverage report filename
items.body:
coverage.py allows for one to choose the filename (defaulting to .coverage). Because of the regexes, some of the possible variations in filenames are not detected (in a project that I recently worked on, the format `.coverage.anywordhere`) was not detected (coverage.py allows variable substitution from the os environment in its configuration and anywordhere was being substituted as either unit or functional depending on the build, for context).

While I've solved my own problem by reordering the format in the config to be `${ENV_VAR}.coverage`; which is just as fine to me, others may want some other naming scheme for a variety of purposes.

A simple CLI argument specifying which report to collect and upload would suffice (this would run instead of the collect reports section)

items.title: C++ / gcov: Incorrect file paths
items.body:
This is about a C++ project.

Previously I was using lcov script to collect and filter coverage data. As the result I had single `coverage.data` file uploaded with `codecov -f` bash script.

Now I switched to codecov-python and I'd like to collect gcov data directly with the script.
The biggest issue is the script is not able to recognize the file location correctly. In the result the same files are listed twice - once in the correct directory, once in project root dir.

PR: https://github.com/ethereum/cpp-ethereum/pull/4526
Report: https://codecov.io/gh/ethereum/cpp-ethereum/tree/6018d53addb1a0a66cdd011e21887ca53f4a7f02
Example file AES.cpp:
https://codecov.io/gh/ethereum/cpp-ethereum/src/6018d53addb1a0a66cdd011e21887ca53f4a7f02/libdevcrypto/AES.cpp
https://codecov.io/gh/ethereum/cpp-ethereum/src/6018d53addb1a0a66cdd011e21887ca53f4a7f02/AES.cpp (file not found).

items.title: codecov doesn't exit with error if upload fails
Add conda-forge package to docs

There is also a conda-forge package for those using conda!
Would it be possible to put this into the docs/readme somewhere?

You can install it with
`conda install -y -c conda-forge codecov`

items.title: Failing on GitLab CI v9+
items.body:
Hi !

So GitLab-CI has been updating from v8 to v9 lately, and they transitioned from *builds* to *job* in their whole nomenclature. As such, some job variables have been renamed, causing `codecov` to crash when called in the CI environment. For instance (this example is actually what makes it crash for me) `CI_BUILD_REPO` has been renamed `CI_REPOSITORY_URL`, so I get the following exception when I try to report:
```shell
      _____          _
     / ____|        | |
    | |     ___   __| | ___  ___ _____   __
    | |    / _ \ / _  |/ _ \/ __/ _ \ \ / /
    | |___| (_) | (_| |  __/ (_| (_) \ V /
     \_____\___/ \____|\___|\___\___/ \_/
                                    v2.0.7

==> Detecting CI provider
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/codecov", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/codecov/__init__.py", line 473, in main
    slug=os.getenv('CI_BUILD_REPO').split('/', 3)[-1].replace('.git', ''),
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'split'
ERROR: Job failed: exit code 1
```

I'll submit a PR shortly.

items.title: Add support for local .git repositories not yet published to github that are on Windows.
items.body:
Currently I can ``pip install --upgrade codecov`` on windows.

However I would like to be able to check the coverage of my latest commits locally so I know weather or not I need to add my tests for some test cases before  I put the repository to github. Is there a way to do this? I can do ``"%SystemDrive%\Python360\python.exe" setup.py test`` that runs pytest and passes the one test the local repository has. I just would like to use this to see how many lines are covered locally and then print the % of the code that is covered.

This is also to ensure proper setup for codecov as well.

Also on travis I see projects like aiohttp doing ``make cov-dev-full``. How can I do that in terms of Windows or AppVeyor when it is on github officially?

items.title: Cannot upload test results that contain characters outside of latin-1
items.body:
For the past several months (at least 3) codecov has failed to work when test results contain unicode characters. Codecov outputs the following:

```
==> Detecting CI provider
    Travis Detected
==> Preparing upload
==> Processing gcov (disable by -X gcov)
    Executing gcov (find /home/travis/build/boto/botocore -type f -name '*.gcno'  -exec gcov -pb  {} +)
==> Collecting reports
    + /home/travis/build/boto/botocore/tests/nosetests.xml bytes=1746359
    Generating coverage xml reports for Python
    + /home/travis/build/boto/botocore/coverage.xml bytes=262229
==> Appending environment variables
    + TRAVIS_PYTHON_NAME
    + TRAVIS_OS_NAME
==> Uploading
    .url https://codecov.io
    .query [redacted]
    Pinging Codecov...
    Uploading to S3...
Error: 'latin-1' codec can't encode character '\u2713' in position 1651009: Body ('✓') is not valid Latin-1. Use body.encode('utf-8') if you want to send it encoded in UTF-8.

Tip: See an example python repo: https://github.com/codecov/example-python
Support channels:
  Email:   hello@codecov.io
  IRC:     #codecov
  Gitter:  https://gitter.im/codecov/support
  Twitter: @codecov
```

I'm unsure why this suddenly stopped working, but it does appear to coincide with the [requests upgrade](https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/commit/7386c3c13fc71f237611c780646fa1b44a07dc64#diff-2eeaed663bd0d25b7e608891384b7298). Regardless, the body should probably be encoded before [sending](https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/blob/master/codecov/__init__.py#L717).

items.title: -e Flag Doesn't Accept Multiple Var Names
items.body:
https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/blob/master/codecov/__init__.py#L246-L249

It should split on `,` like it does at:

https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/blob/master/codecov/__init__.py#L251-L254

items.title: Empty $TRAVIS_PYTHON_NAME included regardless of --env / -e
items.body:
It seems (possibly due to a change on TravisCI), that `$TRAVIS_PYTHON_NAME` is currently empty, e.g.

https://codecov.io/gh/ipython/ipython/commit/c17ff28cb1220a91d94fc0dc4b85ccee561fb68f/builds

https://codecov.io/gh/biopython/biopython/commit/2d7619594003460b61fab62260ce50f6a344ba63/builds

Reading the code for `--env` aka `-e`, the current behaviour is to automatically add some additional environment variables over-riding those specified at the command line, e.g. for TravisCI

``` python
include_env.add('TRAVIS_OS_NAME')
include_env.add('TRAVIS_%s_NAME' % language.upper())
include_env.add('TOXENV')
```

and for Snap:

``` python
include_env.add(os.getenv('DISPLAY'))
```

Having these as the default is nice (if `-env` or `-e` is not used), but to me having them over-ride the command line is surprising. As per #75 the documentation here could be clearer?

items.title: $CODECOV_ENV documentation URL dead
items.body:
From the help text,

```
$ codecov
...
  --env [ENV [ENV ...]], -e [ENV [ENV ...]]
                        Store environment variables to help distinguish CI
                        builds. Example: http://bit.ly/1ElohCu
...
```

Comes from this line:

``` python
basics.add_argument('--env', '-e', nargs="*", default=os.getenv("CODECOV_ENV"), help="Store environment variables to help distinguish CI builds. Example: http://bit.ly/1ElohCu")
```

Sadly http://bit.ly/1ElohCu resolves to https://codecov.io/github/pyca/cryptography/src/cryptography?ref=db86de59b02be0793dea5e862090586c31998ad1 which gives an Error 404

Note the codecov-bash help text is different:

```
    -e ENV       Specify environment variables to be included with this build
                 ex. codecov -e VAR,VAR2
                 (or) set environment variable CODECOV_ENV=VAR,VAR2
```

items.title: See all the environment variables for other CI providers here in README 404s
items.body: The link provided in the text in the README.md leads to a 404 page.

```
C:\Python27\python.exe: No module named codecov.__main__; 'codecov' is a package and cannot be directly executed
Command exited with code 1
```

items.title: coverage parallel not supported
items.body:
When coverage run config `parallel = True`, cmdline option `-p`, `--parallel-mode`, multiple coverage data files are created with machine name, process id and random number appended to the .coverage data file name.

codecov reports "No coverage report found".

items.title: failed to exec coverage
items.body:
On Windows, if the Python "Scripts" directory is not in the `PATH`, and codecov is invoked like `C:\...\Scripts\codecov`, `try_to_run` will fail to exec coverage.  The same could happen on Unix, but it is less likely.

This can be avoided a few ways, e.g. by calling coverage as a Python package, adding the "Scripts" directory to the PATH for the exec, using `sys.executable -m coverage` on Python 2.7+, etc.

items.title: Pull Requests with a '#' in the name cause the coverage report upload to fail
items.body: example: `feature/#123_new_feature`. Using CircleCI

items.title: How does one use --gcov-args?
items.body:
Hi all, trying to pass a parameter to gcov with '--gcov-args'.

As far as I can tell, the args.gcov_args is transmitted verbatim to gcov in the find command
(https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/blob/master/codecov/__init__.py#L567), but argparse won't take any arguments that start with a '-'. I don't find any tests that demonstrate the right way to use it, either. Tips?
thx!

items.title: Codecov.io returns 400 for AppVeyor builds with spaces.
items.body: It seems that spaces need to be encoded as `%20` instead of `+`.

```
Running codecov
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/travis/miniconda/envs/testenv/bin/codecov", line 7, in <module>

  File "/home/travis/miniconda/envs/testenv/lib/python2.6/site-packages/codecov/__init__.py", line 7, in <module>

```

items.title: Allow multiple paths to be passed to -f

From what I undestand, as of now, only a single path can be passed as argument when using codecov -f parameter.

Could multiple files be passed as well, or could this feature be added?

items.title: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position...
items.body:
I get an error while trying to use the uploader for a Go project:
https://github.com/bbalet/stopwords

```
'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 13398-13493: ordinal not in range(128)
```

Apparently, this is a known issue with Python, see:
- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9942594/unicodeencodeerror-ascii-codec-cant-encode-character-u-xa0-in-position-20
- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9942594/unicodeencodeerror-ascii-codec-cant-encode-character-u-xa0-in-position-20

Attached is the log generated by Travis-CI where you can find this error:
[log.txt](https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/files/124394/log.txt)

items.title: project path is wrong if building with gitlab ci runner
items.body:
Hi,

the path used for searching the report data is incorrect if building the project with a gitlab ci runner.

gitlab-ci-multi-runner provides a absolute path for the project directory. It was introduced by [this commit ](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ci-multi-runner/commit/0e50a4334aa0bb162e3e0c845401a369ae9841b0) and included in v0.7.

So it would be nice if you could revert the change introduced in your commit [564bc23f1542dd...](https://github.com/codecov/codecov-python/commit/564bc23f1542dd9de36e11b5867401e4c7a03769)

Thanks and regards
Philip

items.title: Support for Buildkite
items.body:
Hey,

I'd love to see support for buildkite. They expose all the necessary env variables as far as I can see, so integration should be relatively straight-forward: https://buildkite.com/docs/guides/environment-variables

Some things I can set by passing them as arguments to the command, but things like the "pr" parameter are not exposed at the moment, as far as I can see :-)

Thanks!

items.title: Why does codecov use verify=False when upoading to S3?
items.body:
This allows an attacker to see the results or manipulate them.

cc: @reaperhulk, @dstufft

items.title: Not showing lines covered when used by multiprocessing.Process
items.body:
This results in large portions of code showing up as uncovered, despite being covered.

[Example](https://codecov.io/github/gappleto97/Senior-Project/common/peers.py?ref=24db3f7116e0c8c0373a40cb14b74f27f630d156#line-115)

items.title: gitlab-ci-multi-runner `codecov` does not find coverage.xml
items.body:
I try to get `codecov` working on my gitlab-ci.
As runner/slave is use [gitlab-ci-multi-runner](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ci-multi-runner) in `shell` mode, therefore simply using the local shell.

The error message `codecov` prints:

```
No reports found. You may need to add a coverage config file. Visit http://bit.ly/1slucpy for configuration help.Uploaded: False
Report URL: n/a
Upload Version: codecov-v1.1.9
Message: error no coverage report found, could not upload to codecov
```

Do data is uploaded in reality.

You can see the an example build [here](https://ci.gitlab.com/projects/3804/builds/94826)

I also execute `ls -la` and like you see the `coverage.xml` exists and has a file size. All other commands run well with the runner. The runner run all commands in the same directory like usual.

I can type in exactly the same commands on the same machine (where the runner is executed) with the same user (`gitlab_ci_multi_runner`) and everything works well, but not automatically via the CI.

I have no ideas left. Suggestions?

EDIT: Like you see with `ls -la` the _coverage config_ also exists ...

items.title: codecov --help fails out of Git repo
items.body:
Running `codecov --help` outside of a Git repo displays a traceback:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/tmp/vv/bin/codecov", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('codecov==1.1.9', 'console_scripts', 'codecov')()
  File "/tmp/vv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/codecov/__init__.py", line 286, in cli
    data, codecov = main()
  File "/tmp/vv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/codecov/__init__.py", line 259, in main
    branch = subprocess.check_output('git rev-parse --abbrev-ref HEAD', shell=True)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/subprocess.py", line 573, in check_output
    raise CalledProcessError(retcode, cmd, output=output)
subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command 'git rev-parse --abbrev-ref HEAD' returned non-zero exit status 128
```

This is because the check `'-h' not in argv and '--help' not in argv` only works if `argv` is set; else it should check sys.argv (this is what argparse does line 276).

I personally recommend something like `if not argv: argv = sys.argv` at the beginning of main() to avoid unnecessary ifs.

items.title: Extended support for C coverage measurements
items.body:
The current integration is fairly inconvenient for large-ish projects: https://codecov.io/guide#c

Would be very nice if codecov would be able to run gcov and collect everything automatically, just like [cpp-coveralls](https://github.com/eddyxu/cpp-coveralls/blob/master/cpp_coveralls/coverage.py#L178-L270)

items.title: AppVeyor still requires token.
items.body:
I got an email a few weeks ago that said "Integration Using Appveyor CI? You no longer need a repo token for public repos.".

However I'm getting this traceback:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Python34-x64\lib\runpy.py", line 170, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "C:\Python34-x64\lib\runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "C:\Python34-x64\Scripts\codecov.exe\__main__.py", line 9, in <module>
  File "C:\Python34-x64\lib\site-packages\codecov\__init__.py", line 285, in cli
    data, codecov = main()
  File "C:\Python34-x64\lib\site-packages\codecov\__init__.py", line 278, in main
    data = upload(url=codecov.url, branch=codecov.branch, commit=codecov.commit, token=codecov.token, env=codecov.env, slug=codecov.slug, **defaults)
  File "C:\Python34-x64\lib\site-packages\codecov\__init__.py", line 120, in upload
    result.raise_for_status()
  File "C:\Python34-x64\lib\site-packages\requests\models.py", line 851, in raise_for_status
    raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self)
requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 400 Client Error: Bad Request
{"message": "token or build not found", "meta": {"request": "22e2fb93-cad4-485b-8960-bffaacc5ddaf", "status": 400}, "uploaded": false}
```

https://ci.appveyor.com/project/Robpol86/terminaltables/build/1.0.152
https://github.com/Robpol86/terminaltables/tree/1a8e68f10accf7e8097cec9dd52af3befc47b97f

appveyor.yml:

``` yaml
init:
  - set PATH=C:\Python34-x64;C:\Python34-x64\Scripts;%PATH%
install:
  - ps: Start-FileDownload https://raw.github.com/pypa/pip/master/contrib/get-pip.py
  - python get-pip.py
build_script:
  - pip install codecov tox
test_script:
  - tox
  - tox -e combine py34x64 py34 py33x64 py33 py27x64 py27
after_test:
  - mv tests/.coverage .
  - codecov
```

items.title: Codecov prints exception traceback when no token is supplied, even though exit status is 0
items.body:
Calling codecov without a token results in traceback and error messages.
Returning with 0 is OK, since I may not want a build to fail if I do not intend to send the report to codecov. However, in that case, I'd prefer not to have such an error be displayed:

```
Uploaded: False
Report URL: n/a
Upload Version: codecov-v1.1.8
Message: missing token or other required argument(s)
WARNING:rollbar:Got unexpected status code from Rollbar api: 403
Response:
{
  "err": 1,
  "message": "access token not found: 856822f107db4a6a8cd84b69e242378f"
}
ERROR:rollbar:Exception while posting item ApiError(u'access token not found: 856822f107db4a6a8cd84b69e242378f',)
Traceback (most recent call last):
    (...traceback...)    
    raise ApiError(json_data.get('message') or 'Unknown error')
ApiError: access token not found: 856822f107db4a6a8cd84b69e242378f
```

I think a basic "token not provided, report not uploaded" message could be more helpful :wink:

items.title: Support loading token from a file.
items.body: Some CI systems ([buildbot](https://buildbot.net/) for example) default to showing the environment and command-line of all commands run. Thus, it would be useful if there was an option to pass a file-name with the token in it, rather than an argument or environment variable.

items.title: --help wants a repo in cwd
items.body:
That option shouldn't require any repository to be setup. 
Eg:

```
C:\Users\ionel_000>codecov --help
fatal: Not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "c:\Python27\Scripts\codecov-script.py", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('codecov==1.1.7', 'console_scripts', 'codecov')()
  File "c:\Python27\lib\site-packages\codecov\__init__.py", line 240, in cli
    data, codecov = main()
  File "c:\Python27\lib\site-packages\codecov\__init__.py", line 216, in main
    branch = subprocess.check_output('git rev-parse --abbrev-ref HEAD', shell=True)
  File "c:\Python27\lib\subprocess.py", line 573, in check_output
    raise CalledProcessError(retcode, cmd, output=output)
subprocess.CalledProcessError: Command 'git rev-parse --abbrev-ref HEAD' returned non-zero exit status 128
```

items.title: Travis Mac InsecurePlatformWarning
items.body:
I'm using the script to upload coverage reports from Travis on their Mac VM images for iOS development.  Recently, I started seeing the following warning message:

```
/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/requests/packages/urllib3/util/ssl_.py:79: InsecurePlatformWarning: A true SSLContext object is not available. This prevents urllib3 from configuring SSL appropriately and may cause certain SSL connections to fail. For more information, see https://urllib3.readthedocs.org/en/latest/security.html#insecureplatformwarning.
  InsecurePlatformWarning
```

I'm not specifying what version of python to use in the `.travis.yml` file.
Is this something to be fixed on your end?  Or is it a Travis configuration issue?

items.title: False positive report upload
items.body:
The client outputs:

```
Uploaded: True
Report URL: http://codecov.io/bitbucket/saaj/cherrypy?ref=4094%3A18e3f7c08f04
Upload Version: codecov-v1.1.6
Message: Coverage reports upload successfully
```

But it doesn't appear on the website. Originated from #19.
